sectionTitle: D.5: Paryushan and Das Lakshan Parva

tabData.tagHTML: Paryushan and Das Lakshan: The Holiest Festivals

Paryushan Mahä Parva (Shvetämbar tradition) and Das Lakshan Parva (Digambar tradition) are the holiest festivals of the Jain year. These are periods dedicated to fasting, intensive rituals, studying Jain principles, and most importantly, repenting for past wrongdoings and asking for forgiveness from all living beings.

The name Paryushan has several meanings, including'coming together from all directions' and'to burn all types of Karma' (Pari + Ushan). It is a time to purify the soul by observing austerities (tap), minimizing worldly affairs, and focusing on the true nature of the self. Similarly, Das Lakshan focuses on cultivating the ten cardinal virtues of the soul.

These festivals typically occur around August-September. The Shvetämbar observance of Paryushan lasts for eight days, while the Digambar observance of Das Lakshan lasts for ten days, beginning on or the day after the Shvetämbar Paryushan ends.

tabData.title: Five Essential Activities of Paryushan
tabData.description: During the first three days of Paryushan, sermons are delivered on five essential activities that laypeople are required to undertake.

items.content: Leading a non-violent life (Ahimsä), working towards a non-violent world, and supporting animal welfare activities.
Showing respect and affection for fellow human beings and supporting humanitarian activities. It fosters a sense of community and mutual respect.
Observing a fast for three consecutive days. Fasting and other austerities help control desires and shed accumulated karma.
Visiting different Jain temples, libraries, and Upäshrays. This also includes supporting other charitable and religious organizations.
The act of forgiveness. This involves repenting for one's own sins, forgiving others for their faults, and requesting forgiveness from all living beings.

tabData.title: The Ten Cardinal Virtues (Das Lakshan Dharma)
tabData.description: The Digambar tradition dedicates each day of the festival to one of the ten supreme virtues, which are inherent qualities of the soul.

tabData.title: Understanding the Ten Virtues
tabData.description: A deeper look into the meaning of each of the Das Lakshan virtues.

items.content: Not allowing anger to arise, and if it does, rendering it ineffective. It's about cultivating the soul's natural state, which is free of anger and revenge.
Having a softness of heart and polite feelings, free from the passion of pride related to knowledge, power, status, or appearance.
Achieving purity in thought, speech, and action. A person with this quality is not deceitful and lives in a simple, honest way.
Attaining contentment by overcoming greed. Greed is the desire to possess and is a root cause of all sins. Eradicating greed makes the soul practically passionless.
Speaking what is beneficial and refraining from harsh or derogatory language. The virtue of the pure soul is truth.
Disciplining the mind, speech, and body to avoid injuring any living being and to detach from sensual pleasures. True happiness comes from within, not from the senses.
Controlling attachments and aversions. When one stabilizes in their own pure state, abandoning desires, it is known as austerity.
Renouncing a possessive attitude. This applies to both external possessions (wealth, house) and internal possessions (attachment, aversion).
Not having a feeling of ownership over anything. It is easy to give up external things, but harder to give up the internal attachment to them.
From an absolute view, it means staying in the true nature of the soul. From an empirical view, it means controlling the desires of the five senses.

tabData.tagHTML: The Reading of the Kalpa Sutra

In the Shvetämbar tradition, the Kalpa Sutra is read to the congregation from the fourth through the eighth day of Paryushan. Composed by Ächärya Bhadrabähu in the 3rd century B.C., this scripture holds immense significance.

• It describes the rules for monastic life during the rainy season.
  • It contains the biographies of Tirthankars, especially a detailed and poetic account of Lord Mahävir's life, including the 14 auspicious dreams of his mother, Queen Trishalä.
  • It outlines the lineage of the Ganadhars' successors.
On the fifth day of Paryushan, the auspicious dreams of Queen Trishalä are celebrated in a special ceremony.

tabData.title: Samvatsari and Kshamä: The Universal Act of Forgiveness
tabData.description: The final day of Shvetämbar Paryushan is Samvatsari, and the first day of Digambar Das Lakshan is Kshamä Vani. Both are dedicated to the paramount Jain principle of forgiveness.

items.content: On this day, Jains ask for forgiveness from everyone—family, friends, and all other living beings—for any harm caused knowingly or unknowingly during the past year. It is a day to release oneself from the burden of anger, hostility, and resentment.

The essence of this day is captured in the universal prayer:

Khämemi Savva Jive, Savve Jivä Khamantu Me
Mitti Me Savva Bhuesu, Veram Majjha na Kenai.

Translation:
I forgive all living beings,
May all living beings forgive me.
My friendship is with all living beings,
My enmity is nonexistent.

items.header: Why Forgiveness is a'Quality of the Brave'
items.content: Asking for forgiveness requires great humility (Vinay) and the strength to suppress one's ego and anger. As the Ächäryas have said,'Kshamä Virasya Bhushanam' – Forgiveness is the ornament of the brave. When we forgive, we purify our soul and become one with its radiant light.

questions.question: How many days does the Shvetämbar festival of Paryushan last?
Which of these is one of the Five Essential Activities of Paryushan?

What is the name for the final day of Paryushan, dedicated to forgiveness?

options: May all living beings forgive me

'Pari + Ushan' is one meaning of Paryushan. What does it mean?
options: To stay closer to the soul
To burn all types of Karma
To come together from all directions
questions.answer: To burn all types of Karma

questions.question: Which scripture is read daily during the ten days of Das Lakshan Parva?
The phrase'Kshamä Virasya Bhushanam' means:
options: Forgiveness is the ornament of the brave
Forgiveness is the path to liberation
questions.answer: Forgiveness is the ornament of the brave
